sentences.sentence: Global perspective The right has been seduced by the fool's gold of populist leaders.

The British PM's resignation is a chance to focus on long-term economic revival with a clear ideological purpose.The curtains have come down on Boris Johnson's chaotic tenure as British prime minister.

In the past month, he has scraped the endorsement of his parliamentary colleagues, catastrophically lost two byelections, and now been blindsided by two very senior cabinet walkouts and fired another, along with more than 50 junior resignations.

"He has neither the character nor the temperament to be our prime minister", concluded Andrew Mitchell, a party grandee-in-chief, neatly summarising middle opinion in the rebellion among his own troops.The timetable had been set for his very public and brutal guillotining had he sought to stay.
Next week the rules for a second confidence vote would have been amended.
The ructions of the past couple of days mean that finding another 30 of his own MPs to vote against him was an absolute certainty.Now he is toast and a leadership spill is on.

Ex-chancellor Rishi Sunak, who at least has some clear and consistently held economic views, has served notice that the next leader should run a competent government and follow a coherent policy agenda.Regardless of who follows, an entirely new set of problems come to the fore, which will have implications globally.The first is that the British Conservatives are no longer held together by ideological glue.
This truth has been lurking since the Brexit revolt six years ago.

The party's greatest modern spell was characterised and underwritten by an ideological and cultural crusade committed to state contraction, extending market forces and reversing decades of relative economic decline.That Thatcherite agenda paved the way and set the pace for globalisation internationally.
Its success fuelled national economic recovery for a quarter of a century.

Any modern Tory would-be leader should take note.It is delusional to pretend that both electoral and policy success can be forged from assorted grievances about Europe, migration or anything else.Second, his successor must focus on the role of the state post-COVID, which has taught us that, while people like to be told what to do and have their lives run for them, things are more complex.

Although state paternalism is back in demand when all else has failed, these circumstances are only true of the first 12 months of a global public health emergency.The people, in truth, want it both ways.

Even Australia, the infamous larrikin nation, wants to be told what to do.This revelation has understandably scrambled political choices for centre-right parties everywhere since state intervention is now prized as an across-the-board response, accompanied by eye-watering amounts of public spending and faint accountability over how effective it actually is.This distortion has been exaggerated massively for Boris' Tories who have basked in electoral success without ever resolving their purpose in holding office.The lack of significant political differences in UK politics has meant that voters can only judge based on personal conduct.
Johnson and his acolytes have provided plenty of raw material forthem to do so.

To make matters worse,the future leader of his party must also repair trust in government on top of everything else.The third knock-on effect of his defenestration is the biggest, and curiously brings the largest opportunity for renewal.
This moment should trigger a big debate on how mature industrial economies steer future market forces rather than second-guessing - or worse still, replacing - them.

Let's be clear that it is not a debate that US Republicans will join, distracted as they are with resurrecting their equally mercurial leader-in-exile.But elsewhere, the pressure is on and driven by long-term trends in declining economic productivity, ageing workforces, mounting social pressures and mixed evidence about the worth of massive supply-side reform alone.

The UK most exemplifies this challenge but there are loud echoes across Australia, Canada, Japan, and many European nations.Recent years have shown that enough voters in these places are unnerved by mounting inequality and the pace of change.
This environment has been politically toxic and one that has provided a rich source of sustenance for those on the right who have created and promoted their own aggressive brand of identity politics.

They have been seduced by fool's gold, not least in abdicating from the responsibility to explain how a modern economy should be run.The trouble is that this politics has roots that are shallow since so many it purports to speak for are also cross-pressured.

Taking away the welcome mat for EU workers means permanently living with acute staff shortages in hospitals.Johnson's 2019 electoral success was fatally hollow since it had so little to say about the path to long-term economic revival.

And the answer to that question depends on having, if not a settled ideological purpose, at least an ideological compass that allows you to explain to voters what you want to achieve and why.Government by bombastic individual ego is over but that sorry picture must not dictate what happens next.

Its significance lies in enabling the centre-right to get back to political choices that matter.Shamit Saggar is director of The University of Western Australia Public Policy Institute, and a former senior official in the Blair government.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

The British PM's resignation is a chance to focus on long-term economic revival with a clear ideological purpose.The curtains have come down on Boris Johnson's chaotic tenure as British prime minister. In the past month, he has scraped the endorsement of his parliamentary colleagues, catastrophically lost two byelections, and now been blindsided by two very senior cabinet walkouts and fired another, along with more than 50 junior resignations."He has neither the character nor the temperament to be our prime minister", concluded Andrew Mitchell, a party grandee-in-chief, neatly summarising middle opinion in the rebellion among his own troops.The timetable had been set for his very public and brutal guillotining had he sought to stay. This truth has been lurking since the Brexit revolt six years ago. The party's greatest modern spell was characterised and underwritten by an ideological and cultural crusade committed to state contraction, extending market forces and reversing decades of relative economic decline.That Thatcherite agenda paved the way and set the pace for globalisation internationally. Its success fuelled national economic recovery for a quarter of a century. And the answer to that question depends on having, if not a settled ideological purpose, at least an ideological compass that allows you to explain to voters what you want to achieve and why.Government by bombastic individual ego is over but that sorry picture must not dictate what happens next. Its significance lies in enabling the centre-right to get back to political choices that matter.Shamit Saggar is director of The University of Western Australia Public Policy Institute, and a former senior official in the Blair government.
